tr.td: Title:Is there dark matter in the newly discovered luminous stellar clusters in the halo of M31?
Co-I(s): Nial Tanvir, Jim Collett, Mike Irwin, Annette Ferguson, Rodrigo Ibata, Geraint Lewis, Rachel Johnson, Terry Bridges, Scott Chapman

body.div: We have recently discovered a population of luminous star clusters in the far halo of M31. These objects have luminosities typical of globular clusters, but are much more extended (roughly 5-10x greater half-light radius than typical GCs) and have no known counterparts in the Milky-Way. Their stellar populations appear old and metal-poor. The question naturally arises: do these clusters have a dark-matter component (cf. dSphs) or not (cf. GCs)? This is crucial for understanding their origin, and more broadly, if they do reside in dark-matter halos then they would help explain the apparent deficit of small halos compared to theoretical predictions. Here we propose multi-slit GMOS spectroscopy of a sample of stars in one of these clusters, to determine its velocity dispersion and hence M/L. As by-products we will also estimate the spectroscopic metallicity, look for any evidence of kinematic disturbance, and determine the systemic velocity of the cluster.
